facts.text: Petition No. 31 of 1959 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 31 of 1959. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India, for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 10, 1961 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: C. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India, S. N. Andley, B. Dadachanji, Pameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the petitioners. Sen and I. N. Shroff, for the respondent. 1961. February 10.

facts.text: Petition impugns validity of two notices of demand served on petitioners requiring payment of company tax by respondent Local Board.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-This petition under Art. 32 has been filed impugning the validity of two numberices of demand served on the petitioners requiring them to pay what has been companypendiously described as companyl tax by the respondent, which is a Local Board companystituted under the Central Provinces Berar Local Government Act, 1948  C. P. Berar Act XXXVIII of 1948 .

facts.text: Tax imposed by local authority from March 12, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that the tax number impugned has been imposed by the local authority, from March 12, 1935 and that the first occasion when its validity was attacked was in only 1957,

facts.text: First challenge to tax validity in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that the tax number impugned has been imposed by the local authority, from March 12, 1935 and that the first occasion when its validity was attacked was in only 1957, though if the petitioners are right in their submissions their acquiescence might number itself be a ground for denying them relief

facts.text: Petitioners work certain mines situated in the district of Chhindwara.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are working certain mines situated in the district of Chhindwara and for the area companyered by the mines an Independent Mining Local Board was companystituted in or about 1926

facts.text: Independent Mining Local Board constituted in or about 1926.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are working certain mines situated in the district of Chhindwara and for the area companyered by the mines an Independent Mining Local Board was companystituted in or about 1926 and such Boards are included in the definition of a Local Board under the Act

facts.text: Mining Board passed resolution on March 12, 1935 to impose tax on coal, coal-dust and coke at 3 pies per ton.

anchor.surface_text: This Mining Board, after obtaining the previous approval of the local Government, passed on March 12, 1935, by the majority requisite under E. 51 1  of the Act a resolution to impose a tax on companyl, companyl-dust and companye in the following terms The tax shall be levied at the rate of three pies per ton on companyl, companyl dust or companye, manufactured at the mines, sold for export by rail or sold otherwise than for export by rail within the territorial jurisdiction of the Independent Mining Local Board.

facts.text: Tax levied and collected ever since 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The tax has been levied and companylected ever since.

facts.text: Central Provinces Local Self Government Act, 1920 repealed and re-enacted by Central Provinces Berar Local Government Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Local-Self Government Act of 1920 was repealed and re- enacted by the Central Provinces Berar Local Government Act, 1948, but numberhing turns on this, because the later enactment and certain amendments made subsequently companytain provisions for the companytinuance of the Local Boards companystituted under the repealed enactment

facts.text: Respondent constituted under 1948 Act and successor of Independent Mining Board.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was, as stated earlier, companystituted under the Act of 1948 and is admittedly the successor of the Inde- pendent Mining Board which imposed the tax by its resolution dated March 12, 1935, and is legally entitled to companytinue the levy if the original imposition was valid.

facts.text: Rate of tax raised from 3 pies to 9 pies per ton in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: There is only one other matter to be mentioned at this stage, viz., that the rate of duty which, as seen from the resolution extracted earlier, was 3 pies per ton when imposed in 1935 was raised by the local body to 9 pies per ton in 1949, this being the rate which number prevails.

facts.text: Chief Executive Officer of respondent served two notices of demand on August 23, 1958 on first and second petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: On August 23, 1958, the Chief Executive Officer of the respondent-Sabha served two numberices of demand on the first and second petitioners requiring them to pay sums of Rs. 21,898.64 and Rs. 11,838- 09 respectively as the tax due by each,

facts.text: Notices demand Rs. 21,898.64 from first petitioner and Rs. 11,838.09 from second petitioner for coal despatches January 1, 1958 to June 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On August 23, 1958, the Chief Executive Officer of the respondent-Sabha served two numberices of demand on the first and second petitioners requiring them to pay sums of Rs. 21,898.64 and Rs. 11,838- 09 respectively as the tax due by each, for despatches of companyl from their respective mines for the period January 1, 1958, to June 30, 1958.

facts.text: Petitioners claim levy invalid at original imposition in 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The submissions of the learned Attorney-General were three The levy of the tax by the Independent Mining Board was invalid at the date of its original imposition in 1935,

facts.text: Petitioners claim tax ceased to be legal after Government of India Act, 1935 and Constitution of India 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming the levy was valid when originally imposed, it ceased to be legal after the companying into force, first of the Government of India Act, 1935 and later of the Constitution of India in 1950

facts.text: Petitioners claim increase to 9 pies per ton in 1949 illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming further that the provision companytained in s. 143 of the Government of India Act companyered the tax, the protection afforded by it or the companytinuance for which it provided, is only for a tax at the rate of 3 pies per ton prevailing before the companymencement of the Government of India Act  April 1, 1937 , and the increase in the rate to 9 pies per ton in 1949 rendered the levy and the demand illegal

facts.text: Court holds original imposition of tax in 1935 was valid.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the original imposition of the tax in 1935 was valid.

facts.text: Tax continues valid under s.143 of 1935 Act and Art.277 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Both these companystitutional enactments companytain express provisions whereby taxes, cesses, etc., which were previously lawfully levied by local authorities for the purposes of their local areas, might companytinue to be companylected and applied for the same purposes numberwithstanding that those taxes companyld thereafter be imposed only by the Central or the Union Government, as the case may be  Vide s. 143 of the Government of India Act, 1935, and Art. 277 of the Constitution .

facts.text: Act of 1920 passed before Government of India Act 1919 came into force.

anchor.surface_text: At the stage of the arguments, however, it was found. that the Act had become law even prior to the companying into force of the Government of India Act, 1919,

facts.text: Previous sanction of Governor-General obtained for introduction of Act under s.79(2) of 1915 Act.

anchor.surface_text: From the recitals at the beginning of the Act it was found that the previous sanction of the Governor-General had been obtained to the introduction of the measure in the Local Legislature under s. 79 2  of the Government of India Act, 1915-i.e., before s. 80A 3  intro- duced into the Government of India Act, 1919, was brought into force.

facts.text: Government of India Act 1935 commenced April 1, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: and the increase in the rate to 9 pies per ton in 1949 rendered the levy and the demand illegal either in whole or at least in part. We shall number proceed to deal with these points in that order That the imposition of the tax by the Independent Mining Board by resolution dated March 12, 1935, was invalid.

facts.text: Petitioners did not raise point on rate increase in petition.

anchor.surface_text: The last point urged was as regards the validity of the increase in the rate of tax to 9 pies per ton effected in 1949, i.e., after the companymencement of Government of India Act, 1935. This objection was number even hinted in the petition number before us,

issues.text: Whether the levy of the tax was in contravention of s. 80A(3) of the Government of India Act, 1915?

anchor.surface_text: a  that the levy of the tax was in contravention of s. 80A 3  of the Government of India Act, 1915. Section 80A 3  enacted, to quote only the part material The local legislature of any province may not, without the previous sanction of the Governor-General, make or take into consideration any law a  imposing or authorising the imposition of any new tax unless the tax is a tax scheduled as exempted from this provision by rules made under this Act or The taxes

issues.text: Whether s. 51 of the Act was subject to s. 80A(3) of the Government of India Act and the Scheduled Taxes Rules by virtue of the opening words 'Subject to the provision of any law or enactment for the time being in force'?

anchor.surface_text: The second matter urged under this head was based on the meaning to be given to the opening words of s. 51 of the Act Subject to the provision of any law or enactment for the time being in force. it was suggested that the provision contained in s. 80A 3  of the Government of India Act read with the Scheduled Taxes Rules framed under that section constituted a law for the time being in force to which the power to levy the tax was subject.

issues.text: Whether s. 51 of the Act authorised the levy of a tax or cess of the nature of the coal tax?

anchor.surface_text: The last reason assigned for disputing the validity of the original imposition of the tax, was that s. 51 of the Act on its language and in the context of the other provisions referred to in that section, did not authorise the levy of a tax or cess of the nature of the coal tax. We are wholly unable to accept this argument. The relevant words of s. 51 are impose any tax, toll or rate other than those specified in sections 24, 48, 49 and 50.

issues.text: Whether the tax ceased to be legally leviable by reason of the coming into force of the Government of India Act, 1935 and of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the original imposition of the tax in 1935 was valid. The next question is has the tax ceased to be legally leviable by reason of the coming into force of the Government of India Act, 1935 and of the Constitution? Both these constitutional enactments contain express provisions whereby taxes, cesses, etc., which were previously lawfully levied by local authorities

issues.text: Whether the increase in the rate of tax to 9 pies per ton effected in 1949 rendered the levy and the demand illegal?

anchor.surface_text: The last point urged was as regards the validity of the increase in the rate of tax to 9 pies per ton effected in 1949, i.e., after the commencement of Government of India Act, 1935. This objection was not even hinted in the petition nor before us, and we did not consider it proper to permit petitioners to raise the point.

arguments.claim: The levy of the tax by the Independent Mining Board was invalid at the date of its original imposition in 1935 because the Act was passed after the Government of India Act, 1919 introducing s.80A(3) without previous sanction of the Governor-General.

anchor.surface_text: a that the levy of the tax was in contravention of s. 80A 3  of the Government of India Act, 1915. arguments.court_reasoning: Act actually passed before GOI 1919 came into force; previous sanction under s.79(2) GOI 1915 obtained; proviso to s.80A(3) saves as Governor-General assented; s.84(2) general saving.

arguments.claim: Even if s.51 of the Act was valid when enacted, its exercise in 1935 to impose the tax required previous sanction of Governor-General under s.80A(3) GOI Act as then in force.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General, therefore, modified his argument and presented it in this form No doubt when s. 51 of the Act was enacted, it was within the competence of the Local Legislature. But the power conferred by that section to levy the tax was exercised only in 1935 and by that date s. 80A had been introduced into the Government of India Act and thereafter there could be no local imposition of a tax, not included in the Scheduled Taxes Rules without the previous sanction of the Governor-General being obtained.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: This apart, all companytroversy is set at rest and any argument of the type number urged is precluded by r. 5 of the Scheduled Taxes Rules which runs

arguments.court_reasoning: Amendments to GOI 1915 by 1919 do not affect validity of existing s.51; s.80A concerns procedure for new laws, not exercise of existing powers; r.5 Scheduled Taxes Rules expressly saves local authority rights under existing laws.

arguments.claim: Power under s.51(1) is subject to s.80A(3) and Scheduled Taxes Rules via opening words 'Subject to the provision of any law or enactment for the time being in force'.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.80A(3) is procedural for future enactments, not a substantive law; even if, r.5 of rules overrides.

arguments.claim: s.51 does not authorise levy of a tax of the nature of the coal tax, by ejusdem generis with taxes in ss.24,48,49,50.

anchor.surface_text: The last reason assigned for disputing the validity of the original imposition of the tax, was that s. 51 of the Act on its language and in the context of the other provisions referred to in that section, did not authorise the levy of a tax or cess of the nature of the coal tax. We are wholly unable to accept this argument. The relevant words of s. 51 are impose any tax, toll or rate other than those specified in sections 24, 48, 49 and 50.

arguments.court_reasoning: Words 'any tax, toll or rate other than those' preclude ejusdem generis rule.

arguments.claim: Even if originally valid, the tax ceased to be legal after Government of India Act 1935 and Constitution of India 1950 as it became exclusively leviable by Central/Union Government and not covered by savings in s.143 or Art.277.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming the levy was valid when originally imposed, it ceased to be legal after the coming into force, first of the Government of India Act, 1935 and later of the Constitution of India in 1950 under which the tax in question or some portions of it became exclusively leviable by the Central or Union Government and would not be covered by the saving as to previously existing taxes in s. 143 of the Government of India Act, 1935, and subsequently of Art. 277 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.143 GOI 1935 and Art.277 expressly save pre-existing lawful local taxes notwithstanding shift to central lists; alternatively valid under s.292/Art.372 if in provincial/state list.

arguments.claim: The protection under s.143 GOI 1935 covers only the original rate of 3 pies per ton; increase to 9 pies in 1949 renders levy illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming further that the provision contained in s. 143 of the Government of India Act covered the tax, the protection afforded by it or the continuance for which it provided, is only for a tax at the rate of 3 pies per ton prevailing before the commencement of the Government of India Act  April 1, 1937 , and the increase in the rate to 9 pies per ton in 1949 rendered the levy and the demand illegal either in whole or at least in part.

holdings.text: the Act had become law even prior to the coming into force of the Government of India Act, 1919, with the result that the contention raised in the petition based on s. 80A(3) could not be urged

anchor.surface_text: At the stage of the arguments, however, it was found. that the Act had become law even prior to the coming into force of the Government of India Act, 1919, with the result that the contention raised in the petition based on s. 80A 3  could not be urged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act passed before GOI 1919 came into force and previous sanction of Governor-General obtained under s.79(2) GOI 1915; proviso to s.80A(3) and s.84(2) also save

holdings.text: We consider this argument wholly without force

anchor.surface_text: We consider this argument wholly without force. The validity of s. 51 of the Act, when enacted, not being open to any objection under the Government of India Act, 1915, the amendments effected to the Government of India Act, 1915, by the Act of 1919 did not in any manner, or to any extent, expressly or even by implication affect or trench upon the continued validity and operation of that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.80A(3) concerns procedure for enacting new laws, not exercise of powers under existing valid laws; r.5 Scheduled Taxes Rules expressly preserves local authority taxing rights under existing laws

holdings.text: the provision contained in s. 80A(3) of the Government of India Act read with the Scheduled Taxes Rules framed under that section constituted a law for the time being in force to which the power to levy the tax was subject [rejected;] a law like that which is found in s. 80A(3) prescribing a procedure for enacting future Acts of the Local Legislature could not be comprehended within those words. But even if it did, in the face of r. 5 of the Scheduled Taxes Rules, the construction suggested could have no basis

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.80A(3) is procedural prescription for future legislation, not substantive law within 'any law for the time being in force'; r.5 overrides in any case
